title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: First proposed (Wilkinson, Anand, Grossman 2005), grammar graphics defines way concisely breaking graphs semantic components data visualization. Analogous grammar English, grammar graphics tells us “words” used make “sentence”. allows users create complex graphic assembling multiple independent components. open-sourced R package ggplot2 (Hadley Wickham 2010) implemented grammar graphics modifications refinements, leading now called ‘’layered grammar’’. ggplot2 built mapping data geometric objects multiple different layers drawn coordinate system. example, code following layered grammar complete line chart can include: base layer raw data; layer drawing lines; layer specifying x, y labels title; layer legend settings; layer choosing background theme; … functionalities can modularized one several functions. Modules assembled together high level abstraction according “grammar” ggplot2, eventually show graphic desire. Compared plotting functions vanilla R, ggplot2 convenient use, higher flexibility readability. considered one popular R package (H. Wickham 2016).

what: Building a Shiny App with Graphical Visualization
title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: Shiny framework creating web applications R. Shiny apps built R shiny help users interact data instead facing ice-cold coding console. Together ggplot2, provides possibility creating elegant data visualizations large flexibility. Interactive graphical visualizations extremely helpful presentations statistical education (Doi et al. 2016), providing audience clear straight forward view data analysis. However, procedure building fancy shiny app may fancy comes . requires extensive knowledge shiny comes cost heavy tedious programming work: implementation component grammar graphics requires unignorable amount coding; functionalities ggplot2 may able realized easily intuitively shiny (e.g., customization colors); importantly, apart code individual ggplot components, ’s lot extra work assembling real shiny app.

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: manuscript introduce package ggpaintr, package building shiny apps ggplot2 visualizations. Using package, programming work building data-visualization shiny app can dramatically reduced, coding structure rather simplified mimics way ggplot2 works R.

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: goal ggpaintr make easy writing shiny apps. ggpaintr collection highly modularized shiny app components. offers possibility build shiny app ggplot2 data visualization minimum effort. resulting shiny app can achieve broader functionality ggplot GUI, code accomplish much readable logical. package following advantages: Simplicity code using ggpaintr much shorter, also much readable comparing using vanilla shiny functions. Flexibility implemented ready--use modules ggpaintr commonly used ggplot2 arguments. calling modules directly users can achieve almost complex functionality desire. example, shiny app built pacakge can achieve following visualization: Extensibility Moreover, familiar shiny want extend functionality something haven’t implemented, package also offers ability (instructions) providing ui server functions, even adding new modules package (?). ggpaintr user-friendly package. Anyone knowledge ggplot2 can start building shiny app basic ggplot output like one shown , self-teaching ggpaintr less 10 minutes: Sample Iris Shiny App complex options functionalities can added achieved using similar logic within lines code. Currently ggpaintr implemented commonly used ggplot2 functions parameter options. learn details implement next section. expect package useful following scenarios: Statistical education graphics package offers easier flexible way building graphical shiny apps. Statistics instructors can develop interactive graphical UIs specific demands. transforming R’s programming language point--click style, UIs can used introduce different statistical graphics fresh students field. Statistical education R / ggplot2 Along plot, shiny apps built package also interactively show complete R code generating plot. can extremely useful beginners R ggplot2. Graphical demos presentation important characteristic ggpaintr users can customize app based demand preference. implemented modules commonly used functionalities ggplot2, grammar used ggpaintr also similar. long familiar ggplot2, find hard build shiny app. extra knowledge shiny, also ability convert fancier style formal presentation demo.

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: Let’s revisit demo shiny app presented Figure X. selecting dataset, shiny app allows users map variables (columns) dataset x y. generates plot using ggplot2 shows corresponding R code. reactivity mappings built changing mappings variables x y change resulting plot clicking “draw” button. Moreover, changing selected dataset automatically update available choices x y. Without help ggpaintr, building shiny app least requires following steps: UI components x y input$x input$y available dynamically render UI components x y available choices depend selected data set figure generate ggplot2 plot using input$x input$y since inputs strings. One option use aes_string() figure R code generating resulting plot render plot render code might look involved, shiny app needs functionalities? shiny app needs mappings, color fill, add UI component, modify server part inputs can correctly captured. shiny app wants allow users flip coordinates using coord_flip() adding labels using labs(), building shiny app becomes even involved. Additionally, maintaining updating shiny app can challenging well since many aspects shiny app modified. However, can build shiny app using ggpaintr following code. Many things hidden handled functions ggpaintr, talk detail next section. Updating shiny app can relatively easy help ggpaintr: changing ggplot2 alike expression line 51 adding elements output$controlPanel <- renderUI() line 57: can build shiny app updated features shown Figure X. can see shiny app now allows users flip coordinates set labels. plot corresponding R code can updated accordingly well. Extended Iris Shiny App
code: library(ggpaintr) library(shiny) library(tidyverse) library(shinyWidgets) library(palmerpenguins)  # Define UI for application that draws a histogram ui <- fluidPage(      # Application title   titlePanel("ggpaintr demo"),      # Sidebar with a slider input for number of bins   sidebarLayout(     sidebarPanel(       pickerInput("defaultData", "select a default dataset:",                   choices = c("iris", "mtcars","penguins", "faithfuld"),                   selected = "",                   multiple = TRUE,                   options = pickerOptions(maxOptions = 1)),       uiOutput("controlPanel"),       actionButton("draw", "click to draw the plot"),     ),          # Show a plot of the generated distribution     mainPanel(       plotOutput("outputPlot"),       verbatimTextOutput('outputCode')     )   ) )  # Define server logic required to draw a histogram server <- function(input, output) {      control_id <- "control_id"      # data   data_container <- reactive({     req(input$defaultData)     get(input$defaultData)   })      # construct paintr object   paintr_rctv <- reactive({          req(data_container())          paintr(control_id,            data_container(), data_path = input$defaultData,            geom_boxplot(aes(x, y))      )        })      # place ui   output$controlPanel <- renderUI({     req(paintr_rctv())          column(       12,       paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "x"),       paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "y"),     )   })      # take results and plot   observe({     req(paintr_rctv(), data_container(), input$defaultData)     data <- data_container()          paintr_results <- paintr_plot_code(paintr_rctv())          # Plot output     output$outputPlot <- renderPlot({              paintr_results[['plot']]            })          # Code output     output$outputCode <- renderText({              paintr_results[['code']]            })        }) %>% bindEvent(input$draw)       }  # Run the application shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) # add mapping for fill geom_boxplot(aes(x, y, fill)) +   coord_flip +        # allow users to flip coordinate   labs(x, y, title)   # allow users to add labels for x-axis, y-axis, and title # place ui output$controlPanel <- renderUI({   req(paintr_rctv())      column(     12,     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "x"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "y"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "fill"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "coord_flip"), # add UI for coord_flip()     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "labs"),       # add UI for labs()   ) })

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: Making shiny app ggpaintr straightforward. Since UI components mapping (plot settings like coord_flip() labs()) dynamically rendered, need uiOutput(id) UI side serves placeholder dynamically rendered UIs, like line 21 code demo shiny app. Another thing needed UI side action button, closely related design server side. server side, three building blocks need take care : creating paintr_obj object using ggpaintr::paintr() reactive value (line 45). paintr() main function ggpaintr returns paintr_obj object. expects three arguments: id: ID used create namespace shared UI module servers related paintr_obj object. data: dataset used generate plot expr: expression controls functionality included shiny app. Note wrapping paintr_obj reactive() required paintr() function, required reactivity shiny app. Therefore, one can create paintr_obj using paintr() inspect structure elements even outside context shiny app: extract UI element using ggpaintr::paintr_get_ui() (line 62). paintr_get_ui() expects paintr_obj object selected key name ui. selected key name can key name implemented ggpaintr user-defined key name. discussed later detail. paintr_get_ui() returns UI element selected key name returns NULL selected key name included expr paintr(). paintr_get_ui() can used obtain ID selected UI element type = "id". useful since ID UI element selected key name can potentially arbitrary UI function user-defined. generate plot corresponding R code using paintr_plot_code() (line 72) paintr_plot_code() takes paintr_obj object executes module server functions order generate resulting plot using ggplot2 corresponding R code. Note paintr_plot_code() designed wrapped observeEvent(), equivalently combination observe bindEvent introduced Shiny 1.6.0. isolate() environment provided observeEvent() can prevent module server functions execution necessary pieces missing. result, action button controls paintr_plot_code() observeEvent() expected UI side.
code: paintr(   id,   data,   expr,   extra_ui = NULL,   extra_ui_args = NULL,   data_path = "data" ) my_paintr <- paintr("id", iris,                      geom_boxplot(aes(x, y, fill))) paintr_get_ui(   paintr_obj,   selected_ui_name,   type = "ui",   scope = NULL,   verbose = FALSE ) paintr_plot_code(   paintr_obj,   selected_color_rctv = NULL,   selected_fill_rctv = NULL,   color_fill = FALSE,   color_group = FALSE,   userFUN = NULL,   ... )

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: expression expr paintr() essential functionality ggpaintr. controls type plot shiny app can make functionalities shiny app provides. general, valid expr following: geom_<chart> can geom_ functions ggplot2 long required aesthetic mappings correctly provided. <mapping_*> key names aesthetic mapping. Currently, implemented x, y, z, fill, color, shape, size, group. commonly used aesthetic mappings allow users shiny app select variables dataset specific mapping. UI elements mapping key names implemented shinyWidgets::pickerInput(), allow users select deselect. <geom_args_*> key names arguments passed geom_<chart> function. Currently, implemented alpha, size, position, stat. UI elements size alpha accept numeric inputs, UI elements position stat shinyWidgets::pickerInput(), provides list options users. able use strings control position stat included string options. Since position, stat, arguments geom_<chart> can complicated ggplot2. plan sophisticated way handling arguments future. <plot_settings_*> key names functions can modify plot higher layers. Currently, implemented coord_flip, facet_grid, theme_choose, scale_color, scale_fill, theme(legend.position, legend.direction, legend.box), labs(x, y, title, subtitle). Note theme_choose allows users shiny app choose themes list (theme_gray(), theme_classic(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal()) function ggplot2. shows key names ui server part associated key name can customized. Another thing worth noting theme() ggplot2 powerful implementations three parameters: legend.position, legend.direction, legend.box. able implement three parameters require strings instead ggplot2::element_*. labs(x, y, title, subtitle) similar theme(). currently, labs can set labels x, y, title, subtitle. scale_color scale_fill discussed later.

title: Introduction to ggpaintr
text: scale_color scale_fill allow users shiny app manually select colors color fill, respectively. Since color fill similar behaviors, use color explanation. numerical variable mapped color, scale_color_gradient() used, users can select one color low another color high; categorical variable mapped color, scale_color_manual() used, colors selected users passed parameter values scale_color_manual(). categorical variable 11 levels, server function scale_color refuse render ui choosing colors give warning message. ui choosing colors implemented colourpicker::colourInput depends selected variable color fill mapping. , reactivity scale_color color requires existence color user input, thus established time reactive value paintr() created. solve problem, implemented function called scaleColor_build_reactivity(), can establish reactivity color fill. id id used paintr(). ensures modules share name space. paintr_obj reactive value paintr_obj object created paintr() color_or_fill specifies color fill order add reactivity fill demo shiny app, one make following changes: change expression expr include scale_fill establish reactivity: modify ui output: pass reactive object scale_fill_rctv paintr_plot_code()
code: scaleColor_build_reactivity(   id,    paintr_obj,    color_or_fill ) paintr_rctv <- reactive({      req(data_container())      paintr(control_id,            data_container(), data_path = input$defaultData,            geom_boxplot(aes(x, y, fill)) +                coord_flip +                labs(x, y, title) +                scale_fill     ) })  scale_fill_rctv <- scaleColor_build_reactivity(control_id, paintr_rctv, "fill") output$controlPanel <- renderUI({     req(paintr_rctv())      column(         12,         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "x"),         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "y"),         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "fill"),         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "coord_flip"),         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "labs"),         paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "scale_fill") # added for scale_fill     ) }) paintr_results <- paintr_plot_code(paintr_rctv(),                                    selected_fill_rctv = scale_fill_rctv)

code: library(ggpaintr) library(shiny) library(tidyverse) library(shinyWidgets) library(palmerpenguins)  # Define UI for application that draws a histogram ui <- fluidPage(      # Application title   titlePanel("ggpaintr demo"),      # Sidebar with a slider input for number of bins   sidebarLayout(     sidebarPanel(       pickerInput("defaultData", "select a default dataset:",                   choices = c("iris", "mtcars","penguins", "faithfuld"),                   selected = "",                   multiple = TRUE,                   options = pickerOptions(maxOptions = 1)),       uiOutput("controlPanel"),       actionButton("draw", "click to draw the plot"),     ),          # Show a plot of the generated distribution     mainPanel(       plotOutput("outputPlot"),       verbatimTextOutput('outputCode')     )   ) )  # Define server logic required to draw a histogram server <- function(input, output) {      control_id <- "control_id"      # data   data_container <- reactive({     req(input$defaultData)     get(input$defaultData)   })      # construct paintr object   paintr_rctv <- reactive({          req(data_container())          paintr(control_id,            data_container(), data_path = input$defaultData,            geom_boxplot(aes(x, y))      )        })      # place ui   output$controlPanel <- renderUI({     req(paintr_rctv())          column(       12,       paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "x"),       paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "y"),     )   })      # take results and plot   observe({     req(paintr_rctv(), data_container(), input$defaultData)     data <- data_container()          paintr_results <- paintr_plot_code(paintr_rctv())          # Plot output     output$outputPlot <- renderPlot({              paintr_results[['plot']]            })          # Code output     output$outputCode <- renderText({              paintr_results[['code']]            })        }) %>% bindEvent(input$draw)       }  # Run the application shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) # add mapping for fill geom_boxplot(aes(x, y, fill)) +   coord_flip +        # allow users to flip coordinate   labs(x, y, title)   # allow users to add labels for x-axis, y-axis, and title # place ui output$controlPanel <- renderUI({   req(paintr_rctv())      column(     12,     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "x"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "y"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "fill"),     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "coord_flip"), # add UI for coord_flip()     paintr_get_ui(paintr_rctv(), "labs"),       # add UI for labs()   ) })

what: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
text: Construct paintr_obj based expression ggplot2 alike layout

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
code: paintr(   id,   data,   expr,   extra_ui = NULL,   extra_ui_args = NULL,   data_path = "data" )

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
text: id ID string corresponds ID used component paintr_obj data dataset plotting expr ggplot2 alike expression referred "paintr expression" ggpaintr extra_ui named list: extra functions generate paintr_ui. names list key words paintr expression example extra_ui = list(param1 = my_ui_func1, param2 = my_ui_func2) extra_ui_args named list: lists arguments. names list key words paintr expression. element key word list arguments goes ui function key word example list(param1 = list(my_ui_func1_arg1, my_ui_func1_arg2), param2 = list(my_ui_func2_arg1, my_ui_func2_arg2)) data_path string. path dataset; used code obtaining data

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
text: paintr_obj contains pieces paintr expression corresponding ui elements used build shiny app. Additionally, includes: id data data_path

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
text: expr ggplot2 alike layout wrapped rlang::expr. functionality paintr based expr follows certain rules. general, ggpaintr expression :   note : <mapping_*> mapping keyword represents aesthetic mapping ggplot2, like x, y, color <geom_args_*> geom_args keyword represents argument passed geom_<chart>, like position <plot_settings_*> plot_settings keyword represents ggplot2 function like coord_flip, can modify plot geom_<chart> specifies geom function used plot. 'geom_'used identify geom_<chart> aes used distinguish mapping keywords geom_args keywords geom_<chart>

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
text: extraFunc extraFuncArgs allow users override ui functions provided ggpaintr package

title: Construct a paintr_obj based on an expression in ggplot2 alike layout — paintr
